title: Fast Hybrid Network Algorithms for Shortest Paths in Sparse Graphs

sections.further related work:
As theoretical models for hybrid networks have only been proposed recently, only few results for such models are known at this point  [ref]7 .
Computing an exact solution for SSSP in arbitrary graphs can be done in O~​(SPD)~𝑂SPD\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{\textsf{SPD}}) rounds , where SPD is the so-called shortest path diameter of G𝐺G.
For large SPD, this bound has recently been improved to O~​(n2/5)~𝑂superscript𝑛25\widetilde{O}(n^{2/5}) .
The authors of  also present several approximation algorithms for SSSP: A (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-approximation with runtime O~​(n1/3/ε6)~𝑂superscript𝑛13superscript𝜀6\widetilde{O}(n^{1/3}/\varepsilon^{6}), a (1/ε)O​(1/ε)superscript1𝜀𝑂1𝜀(1/\varepsilon)^{O(1/\varepsilon)}-approximation running in O~​(nε)~𝑂superscript𝑛𝜀\widetilde{O}(n^{\varepsilon}) rounds and a 2O​(log⁡n​log⁡log⁡n)superscript2𝑂𝑛𝑛2^{O(\sqrt{\log n\log\log n})}-approximation with runtime 2O​(log⁡n​log⁡log⁡n)superscript2𝑂𝑛𝑛2^{O(\sqrt{\log n\log\log n})}.
For APSP there is an exact algorithm that runs in O~​(n2/3)~𝑂superscript𝑛23\widetilde{O}(n^{2/3}) rounds, a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-approximation running in O~​(n/ε)~𝑂𝑛𝜀\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n/\varepsilon}) rounds (only for unweighted graphs) and a 333-approximation with runtime O~​(n)~𝑂𝑛\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n}) .
In , the authors give a lower bound of Ω~​(n1/3)~Ωsuperscript𝑛13\widetilde{\Omega}(n^{1/3}) rounds for computing the diameter in arbitrary graphs in our model.
They also give approximation algorithms with approximation factors (3/2+ε)32𝜀(3/2+\varepsilon) and (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon) that run in time O~​(n1/3/ε)~𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀\widetilde{O}(n^{1/3}/\varepsilon) and O~​(n0.397/ε)~𝑂superscript𝑛0.397𝜀\widetilde{O}(n^{0.397}/\varepsilon), respectively.
Even though APSP and the diameter problem are closely related, we demonstrate that the diameter can be computed much faster in our hybrid network model for certain graphs classes. As already pointed out, the global network in our model has a close connection to overlay networks.
The NCC model, which has been introduced in [ref]7, mainly focuses on the impact of node capacities, especially when the nodes have a high degree.
Since, intuitively, for many graph problems the existence of each edge is relevant for the output, most algorithms in [ref]7 depend on the arboricity a𝑎a of G𝐺G (which is, roughly speaking, the time needed to efficiently distribute the load of all edges over the network).
The authors present O~​(a)~𝑂𝑎\widetilde{O}(a) algorithms for local problems such as MIS, matching, or coloring, an O~​(D+a)~𝑂𝐷𝑎\widetilde{O}(D+a) algorithm for BFS tree, and an O~​(1)~𝑂1\widetilde{O}(1) algorithm to compute a minimum spanning tree (MST).
Recently, O~​(Δ)~𝑂Δ\widetilde{O}(\Delta)-time algorithms for graph realization problems have been presented [ref]6, where ΔΔ\Delta is the maximum node degree; notably, most of the algorithms work in the NCC0 variant.
Furthermore, Robinson  investigates the information the nodes need to learn to jointly solve graph problems and derives a lower bound for constructing spanners in the NCC.
For example, his result implies that spanners with constant stretch require polynomial time in the NCC, and are therefore harder to compute than MSTs.
Since our global network behaves like an overlay network, we can make efficient use of the so-called shortest-path diameter reduction technique .
By adding shortcuts between nodes in the global network, we can bridge large distances quickly throughout our computations. Our work also relates to the literature concerned with overlay construction     4 5, where the goal is to transform a low-degree weakly-connected graph into a low-depth overlay network such as a binary tree using node introductions.
Recently, 5 showed a randomized O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n) time overlay construction algorithm for the NCC0 model, if the initial degree is constant.
Our algorithms directly yield a deterministic O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n) time alternative for pseudotrees.
It may be interesting to see whether our results can be used to compute deterministic overlay construction algorithms for sparse graphs. A problem closely related to SSSP is the computation of short routing paths between any given nodes.
The problem has, for example, been studied in mobile ad-hoc networks 9, in which constant-competitive routing paths can be computed in O​(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n) rounds 5.
The authors consider a hybrid network model similar to , where nodes can communicate using either their WiFi-interface (similar to the local edges) or the cellular infrastructure (similar to global edges). In the classical CONGEST model there is a lower bound of Ω~​(n+D)~Ω𝑛𝐷\widetilde{\Omega}(\sqrt{n}+D) rounds to approximate SSSP with a constant factor .
This bound is tight, as there is a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-approximation algorithm by Becker et al. that runs in O~​(n+D)~𝑂𝑛𝐷\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n}+D) rounds .
The best known algorithms for computing exact SSSP in the CONGEST model are the ones by Ghaffari and Li 1 and by Forster and Nanongkai  which have runtimes of O~​(n⋅D)~𝑂⋅𝑛𝐷\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n\cdot D}) and O~​(n​D1/4+n3/5+D)~𝑂𝑛superscript𝐷14superscript𝑛35𝐷\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n}D^{1/4}+n^{3/5}+D), respectively.
Computing the diameter can be done in O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) rounds in the CONGEST model , which is also tight to the lower bound .
This lower bound even holds for very sparse graphs .
In addition to that, the obvious lower bound of Ω​(D)Ω𝐷\Omega(D) for shortest paths problems also always holds if the graph is sparse.
Therefore, algorithms for sparse graphs have been proposed mainly for local problems such as vertex coloring, maximal matching or maximal independent set.
There exists an abundance of literature that studies such problems, for example, in graphs with bounded arboricity 2 0 2, planar graphs  8 9 0 or degree-bounded graphs . Somewhat related to the NCC model, although much more powerful, is the congested clique model, which has received quite some attention in recent years.
A (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-approximation for SSSP can be computed in O​(polylog​(n))𝑂polylog𝑛O(\text{polylog}(n)) rounds in this model 6.
In 7, techniques for faster matrix multiplication in the congested clique model are presented, resulting in a O​(n1−2/ω)𝑂superscript𝑛12𝜔O(n^{1-2/\omega})-round algorithm, where ω<2.3728639𝜔2.3728639\omega<2.3728639 is the exponent of matrix multiplication.
Our algorithm for sparse graphs also uses matrix multiplication in order to compute APSP between O​(n1/3)𝑂superscript𝑛13O(n^{1/3}) nodes in the network in O​(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n) rounds.
In general, the results in the congested clique model are of no help in our setting because due to the restriction that a node can only send or receive O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n) messages per round via global edges, we cannot effectively emulate congested clique algorithms in the NCC model. As argued before, we could apply some of the algorithms for PRAMs to our model instead of using native distributed solutions by using Lemma A.1 in Appendix A for PRAM simulations.
For example, we are able to use the algorithms of 4 to solve SSSP and diameter in trees in time O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n), w.h.p.
Furthermore, we can compute the distance between any pair s𝑠s and t𝑡t in outerplanar graphs in time O​(log3⁡n)𝑂superscript3𝑛O(\log^{3}n) by simulating a CREW PRAM.
For planar graphs, the distance between s𝑠s and t𝑡t can be computed in time O​(log3⁡n​(1+M​(q))/n)𝑂superscript3𝑛1𝑀𝑞𝑛O(\log^{3}n(1+M(q))/n), w.h.p., where the nodes know a set of q𝑞q faces of a planar embedding that covers all vertices, and M​(q)𝑀𝑞M(q) is the number of processors required to multiply two q×q𝑞𝑞q\times q matrices in O​(log⁡q)𝑂𝑞O(\log q) time in the CREW PRAM. For graphs with polylogarithmic arboricity, a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-approximation of SSSP can be computed in polylog time using 6 and our simulation framework (with huge polylogarithmic terms).
For general graphs, the algorithm can be combined with well-known spanner algorithms for the CONGEST model (e.g., 1) to achieve constant approximations for SSSP in time O~​(nε)~𝑂superscript𝑛𝜀\widetilde{O}(n^{\varepsilon}) time in our hybrid model.
This yields an alternative to the SSSP approximation of , which also requires time O~​(nε)~𝑂superscript𝑛𝜀\widetilde{O}(n^{\varepsilon}) but has much smaller polylogarithmic factors.
